titleStmt.title: Neptunes triumph for the returne of Albion celebrated in a masque at the court on the Twelfth night 1623.
titleStmt.author: Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637.

note.p: The year on the title page is given according to Lady Day dating.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: NEPTVNES TRIVMPH for the returne of ALBION, celebrated in a Masque at the Court on the Twelfth night 1623.

epigraph.quote: Omnis & ad reducem iam litat ara Deunt.

div.head: NEPTVNES TRIVMPH.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Then, Brother Poet,

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: I haue a suite.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Your deuise.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: As you came in vpon me, I was then
Offring the argument, and this it is.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: The mightie Neptune, mightie in his styles,
And large command of waters, and of Isles,
Not, as the Lord and Soueraigne of the Seas,
But, Chiefe in the art of riding, late did please
To send his Albion forth, the most his owne,
Vpon discouery, to themselues best knowne,
Through Celtiberia; and, to assist his course,
Gaue him his powerfull e e A NEPT by which cald 〈◊〉 Dame● confe● person ciall how the Albion as by 〈◊〉 vid. 〈◊〉 MANAGER of Horse,
With diuine Proteus, Father of disguise,
To waite vpon them with his counsels wise,
In all extremes. His great commands being done,
And he desirous to review his Sonne,
He doth dispatch a floting Ile, from hence,
Vnto the Hesperian shores, to waft him thence.
Where, what the arts were, vsde to make him stay,
And how the Syrens woo'd him, by the way,
What Monsters he encountred on the coast,
How neare our generall Ioy was to be lost,
Is not our subiect now: though all these make
The present gladnesse greater, for their sake.
But what the triumphs are, the feast, the sport,
And proud solemnities of Neptunes Court,
Now he is safe, and Fame's not heard in vaine,
But we behold our happie pledge againe.
That with him, loyall HIPPIVS is returnd,
Who for it, vnder so much envie, burnd
With his owne brightnes, till her steru'd snakes saw
What Neptune did impose, to him was law.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: But, why not this, till now?

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: — It was not time,
To mixe this Musick with the vulgars chime.
Stay, till th'abortiue, and extemporall dinne
Of balladry, were vnderstood a sinne,
Minerua cry'd: that, what tumultuous verse,
Or prose could make, or steale, they might reherse,
And euery Songster had sung out his fit;
That all the Countrey, and the Citie-wit,
Of bels, and bonfires, and good cheere was spent,
And Neptunes Guard had drunk al that they meant;
That all the tales and stories now were old
Of the Sea-Monster Archy, or growne cold:
The Muses then might venter, vndeterr'd,
For they loue, then, to sing, when they are heard.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: I like it well, tis handsome: And I haue
Some thing wold fit this. How do you present 'hem?
In a fine Iland, say you?

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Yes, a f f Vid. Lucian. in Dialog● & Neptune Delus:
Such, as when faire Latena fell in trauaile,
Great Neptune made emergent.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: I conceive you.
I would haue had your Ile brought floting in, now
In a braue broth, and of a sprightly greene,
Iust to the colour of the Sea; and then,
Some twentie Syrens, singing in the kettel,
With an Arion, mounted on the backe
Of a growne Conger, but in such a posture,
As, all the world should take him for a Dolphin:
O, 'twould ha' made such musick! Ha' you nothing,
But a bare Island?

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Yes, we haue a tree too,
Which we do call the Tree of Harmonie,
And is the same with g g Vid. St Geogr. Lib. what we read, the Sunne
Brought forth in the Indian Musicana first,
And thus it growes. The goodly bole, being got
To certaine cubits height, from euery side
The boughs decline, which taking roote afresh,
Spring vp new boles, & those spring new, & newer,
Till the whole tree become a Porticus,
Or arched Arbour, able to receiue
A numerous troupe, such as our Albion,
And the Companions of his iourney are.
And this they sit in

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Your prime Masquers?

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: But where's your Antimasque now, all this while?
I hearken after them.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Faith, we haue none.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: None?

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: None, I assure you, neither do I think them
A worthy part of presentation,
Being things so heterogene, to all deuise,
Meere By-works, and at best Out-landish nothings.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: O, you are all the heauen awrie! Sir.
For blood of Poetry, running in your veines,
Make not your selfe so ignorantly simple.
Bycause Sir, you shall see I am a Poet,
No lesse then Cooke, and that I find you want
A speciall service here, an Antimasque,
Ile fit you with a dish out of the Kitchin,
Such, as I thinke, will take the present palates,
A metaphoricall dish! And, do but mark,
How a good wit may iump with you. Are you ready, Child?
(Had there bin Maske, or no Maske, I had made it.)
Child of the boyling house.

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: Here, Father.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Bring forth the pot. It is an Olla Podrida,
But I haue persons, to present the meates.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Persons!

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Such as doe relish nothing, but di stato,
(But in another fashion, then you dreame of)
Know all things the wrong way, talk of the affaires,
The clouds, the cortines, and the mysteries
That are afoot, and, from what hands they haue 'hem
(The master of the Elephant, or the Camels)
What correspondences are held; the Posts
That go, & come, and know, almost, their minutes,
All but their businesse: Therein, they are fishes.
But ha' their garlick, as the Prouerb sayes,
They are our Quest of enquiry, after newes.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Together with their learned Authors?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
And of the Epicoene gender, Hees, and Shees:
Amphibion Archy is the chiefe.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: Good boy!
The Child is learned too. Note but the Kitchin.
Haue you put him, into the pot, for Garlick?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: One in his coate, shall stinke as strong as he, Sir,
And his friend Giblets with him.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: They are two,
That giue a part of the seasoning.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: I conceiue
The way of your Gally-mawfrey.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: You will like it,
When they come powring out of the pot together.

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: O, if the pot had been big enough!

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: What then, Child?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: I had put in the Elephant, and one Camell,
at least, for Biefe.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: But, whom ha' you for Partrich?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: A brace of Dwarfes, and delicate plump birds!

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: And whom for Mutton, and Kid?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: A fine lac'd Mutton,
Or two; and either has her frisking Husband:
That reades her the Corrantos, euery weeke.
Graue Mr Ambler, Newes-master of Poules,
Supplies your Capon; and growne Captaine Buz
(His Emissary) vnderwrites for Turky,
A Gentleman of the Forrest presents Phesant,
And a plump Poultrers wife, in Graces street,
Playes Hen with egges i'the belly, or a Cony,
Choose which you will.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: But, where's the Bacon, Thom?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: Hogrel the Butcher, and the Sow his wife,
Are both there.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: It is well, go, dish 'hem out.
Are they well boyld?

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: Podrida!

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: What's that? rotten?

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: O, that they must be. There's one maine ingredient
We haue forgot, the Artichoke.

sp.speaker: CHILD.
sp.l: No Sir.
I haue a Fruicterer, with a cold red nose,
Like a blue fig, performes it.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.l: The fruit lookes so.
Good child, go poure hem out, shew their concoction.
They must be rotten boyld, the broth's the best on't,
And that's the Dance. The stage here is the Charger.
And Brother Poet, though the serious part
Be yours, yet, envie not the Child his art.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Not I. Nam lusis ipse Triumphus amat.
sp.p: The Antimaske is daunc'd by the persons describ'd, comming out of the pot.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Well, now, expect the Scene it selfe; it opens!

div.p: The Iland is discovered, the Masquers sitting in their severall sieges. The heavens opening, and Apollo, with Mercury, some Muses, & the Goddesse Harmony, make the musique. the while, the Iland moues forward, Proteus sitting below, and APOLLO sings.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: Looke forth, the (h) Shephard of the seas, ●teus ●maris. ●tunus, artubus 〈◊〉
And (i) of the Ports, that keep'st the keyes,
And to your Neptune tell,
His ALBION, Prince of all his Isles,
For whome the sea, and land so smiles,
Is home returned well.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: And be it thought no common Cause,
That, to it, so much wonder drawes,
And all the Hea'uens consent,
With HARMONY, to tune their notes,
In answer to the publique votes
That, for it, vp were sent.
It was no envious Stepdames rage,
Or Tyrans malice of the age,
That did employ him forth.
But such a Wisdome, that would proue,
By sending him, their hearts, and loue
That else might feare his worth.

div.p: By this time, the Island hath joynd it selfe with the shore: And Proteus, Portunus, and k k The 〈◊〉 nauigat● with St● Aristid. and Fair Corinth● whence● prouerb frequent the Gre● {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman}, Sarone magis nauticus. Saron; come forth, and goe vp singing to the State, while the Masquers take time to Land.

sp.speaker: PROTHEVS.
sp.l: I! now the Pompe of Neptunes triumph shines!
And all the glories of his great designes
Are read, reflected, in his sonnes returne!

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: How all the eyes, the lookes, the hearts here, burne
at his arriuall!

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: These are the true fires,
Are made of ioyes!

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Of longings!

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Of desires!

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: Of hopes!

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Of feares!

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Not intermitted blocks.

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: But pure affections, and from odorous stocks!

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Tis incense all, that flames!
And these materials scarce haue names!

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: My King lookes higher, as he scornd the warres
Of winds, and with his trident touchd the starrs.
There is no wrinkle, in his brow, or frowne,
But, as his cares he would in nectar drowne, Epithete●nt in 〈◊〉, and of giuen am to 〈◊〉 Panope, 〈◊〉 &c. 〈◊〉
And all the (l) siluer-footed Nymphs were drest,
To wayte vpon him, to the Oceans feast.

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Or, here in rowes vpon the bankes were set,
And had their seuerall hayres made into net
To catch the youths in, as they come on shore.

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: How! Galatea sighing! O, no more.
Banish your feares.

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS,
sp.l: And Doris dry your teares.
Albion is come:

sp.speaker: PORTEVS.
sp.l: And (m) Haliclyon, too, ●ari incly●●renoumd a.) Another Neptunes at●●tes, and 〈◊〉 to the 〈◊〉 person 〈◊〉 Hippius.
That kept his side, as he was charg'd to do,
With wonder.

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: — And the Syrens haue him not.

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Though they no practise, nor no arts forgot
That might haue wonne him, or by charme, or song.

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Or laying forth their tresses all along
Vpon the glassie waues;

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Then diuing:

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Then,
Vp with their heads, as they were mad of men.

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: And there, the highest-going billowes crowne,
Vntill some lusty Sea-god pull'd them downe,

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: See! He is here!

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Great Master of the mayne,
Receiue thy deare, and precious pawne againe.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: SAKON, PORTVNVS, PROTEVS bring him thus,
Safe, as thy Subiects wishes gaue him vs:
And of thy glorious Triumph let it be
No losse a part, that thou their loues doest see,
Then, that his sacred hea'd's return'd to thet.
sp.p: This sung, the Island goes backe, whilst the vpper Chorus takes it from them, and the Masquers prepare for their figure.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Spring all the Graces of the age,
And all the Loues of time;
Bring all the pleasures of the stage,
And relishes of rime:
Adde all the softnesses of Courts
The lockes, the laughters, and the sports.
And mingle all their sweets, and salts,
That none may say, the Triumph halts.

div.p: Here, the Masquers dance their Entry.
Which done, the first prospectiue of a maritime Palace, or the house of Oceanus is discovered, with lowd Musique.
And the other aboue is no more seene.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Behold the Palace of Oceanus!
Hayle Reverend structure! Boast no more to vs
Thy being able, all the Gods to feast;
We haue seene enough: our Albion was thy guest.

div.p: After which the second prospect of the sea, is showne, to the former Musique.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: Now turne and view the wonders of the deepe,
Where Proteus heards, and Neptunes orkes do keep,
Where all is plough'd, yet still the pasture greene
The wayes are found, and yet no path is seene,

div.p: There Proteus, Portunus, Saron, goe vp to the Ladies with this Song.

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Come noble Nymphs, and doe not hide
The ioyes, for which you so prouide:

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: If not to mingle with the men,
What doe you here? Go home agen.

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: Your dressings doe confesse
By what we see so curious parts
Of Pallas, and Arachnes arts,
That you could meane no lesse.

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Why doe you were the Silkewormes toyles;
Or glory in the shellfish spoiles?
Or striue to shew the graines of ore
That you haue gatherd on the shore,
Whereof to make a stocke
To graft the greener Emerald on
Or any better-waterd stone?

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: Or Ruby of the rocke?

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Why do you smell of Ambergris,
Of which was formed Neptunes Neice,
The Queene of Loue; vnlesse you can
Like Sea-borne Venus loue a man?

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: Try, put your selues vnto't.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Your lookes your smiles, and thoughts that meete,
Ambrosian hands, and siluer feete,
doe promise you will do't.

div.p: Which ended, the Fleete is discouered, while the three Cornets play.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: 'Tis time, your eyes should be refresh'd at length
Which something new, a part of Neptunes strength
See, yond, his fleete, ready to goe, or come,
Or fetch the riches of the Ocean home,
So to secure him both in peace, and warres,
Till not one ship alone, but all be starres.

sp.speaker: COOKE.
sp.p: I haue another seruice fer you, Brother Poet, a dish of pickled Saylors, fine salt Sea-boyes, shall relish like Anchoues, or Caueare, to draw downe a cup of nectar, in the skirts of a night.

sp.speaker: SAYLORS.
sp.p: Come away boyes, the Towne is ours, hay for Neptune, and our young Master.

sp.speaker: POET.
sp.l: He knowes the Compasse and the Card,
While Castor sits on the maine yard,
And Pollux too, to helpe your sayles;
And bright Leucothoe, fils your sayles:
Arion sings, the Dolphins swim,
And, all the way, to gaze on him.

div.p: The last Song to the whole Musique, fiue Lutes, three Cornets, and ten voyces.

sp.speaker: PROTEVS.
sp.l: Although we wish the Triumph still might last
For such a Prince, and his discouery past,
Yet now, great Lord of waters, and of Isles,
Giue Proteus leaue to turne vnto his wiles:

sp.speaker: PORTVNVS.
sp.l: And, whilst young Albion doth thy labours ease,
Dispatch Portunus to thy ports,

sp.speaker: SARON.
sp.l: And Saron to thy Seas:
To meete old Nereus, with his fiftie girles,
From aged Indus laden home with pearls,
And orient gummes, to burne vnto thy name.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: And may thy Subiects hearts be all on flame:
Whilst thou dost keepe the earth in firme estate,
And, 'mongst the winds, dost suffer no debate.
But both at sea, and land, our powers increase,
With health, and all the golden gifts of peace.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
